full_title_en: TNM Staging for Renal Cell Carcinoma (RCC) (8th Edition)
medium_description_en: Stages RCC based on tumor, lymph nodes, and metastases (recommended as of 2017).
instructions_en:
• Should be used to classify all RCC patients at the time of diagnosis.

  • The TNM staging is evaluated at diagnosis and is unchanged with disease progression or development of metastasis (TNM stage at diagnosis remains the one).

seo.meta_description_en: The TNM Staging for Renal Cell Carcinoma (RCC) (2017) stages renal cell carcinoma based on tumor, lymph node, and metastasis characteristics.
seo.keywords_en: Kidney, tumor, tumour, lymph node, mets, metastasis, cancer, tnm, rcc ca, rcc cancer, rcc CA tnm, situ, lobular rcc ca, rcc tumor, rcc lymph, rcc mets, rcc metastasis, TNM Staging for rcc cancer, kidney cancer, kidney ca, kidney ca tnm, rcc cancer tnm, rcc cancer staging, renal cell clear cell, kidney cancer

how_to_use.use_case_en: Patients with RCC, at the time of diagnosis.
how_to_use.pearls_pitfalls_en:
• Created and adopted by the Union for International Cancer Control (UICC) and the American Joint Committee on Cancer (AJCC) and last updated in 2017.

  • Used to classify patients with RCC and determine their prognosis at diagnosis.

  • The prognosis estimates are based on cancer-specific survival, not overall survival.

  • Minor modifications were made compared to the previous version published in 2009 in relation to the T3a subgroup only (Paner 2018):

    • The word “grossly” is no longer used to describe renal vein and segmental branch invasion.

    • “Muscle containing” was changed to “segmental vein”.

    • The invasion of the pelvi-caliceal system was added as a rule for classifying patients as T3a.
how_to_use.why_use_en:
• Essential in estimating the prognosis of patients with newly diagnosed RCC.

  • Also determines the treatment options for patients:

    • Local therapy for localized disease or surgically resectable disease.

    • Systemic therapy for metastatic disease or non-surgically resectable disease.

  • Often a prerequisite for deciding whether a patient is eligible for a clinical trial.

next_steps.advice_en:
• TNM staging of RCC patients is the initial step in deciding the management strategy for these patients.

  • Based on the TNM classification, patients can be divided first into metastatic or non-metastatic RCC, and subsequently into more refined classes based on loco-regional invasion and primary tumor size.
next_steps.management_en: Patients with localized or loco-regional disease can be considered for surgical therapy or focal therapy, whereas patients with advanced or metastatic disease often require systemic therapy (NCCN Guidelines 2019).
next_steps.critical_actions_en:
• All newly diagnosed patients with RCC should be staged by TNM.

  • As for all TNM staging systems, remember to include the appropriate prefix to determine how staging was performed:

    • c: Clinical.

    • p:  Pathological.

    • y: Patient received neoadjuvant therapy before staging.

about.formula_en:
Primary tumor (T)

TX

Primary tumor cannot be assessed

T0

No evidence of primary tumor

T1

Tumor ≤7 cm in greatest dimension, limited to the kidney

T1a: Tumor ≤4 cm in greatest dimension, limited to the kidney

T1b: Tumor >4 to 7 cm in greatest dimension, limited to the kidney

T2

Tumor >7 cm in greatest dimension, limited to the kidney

T2a: Tumor >7 to 10 cm in greatest dimension, limited to the kidney

T2b: Tumor >10 cm in greatest dimension, limited to the kidney

T3

Tumor extends into major veins or perinephric tissues, but not into ipsilateral adrenal gland and not beyond Gerota’s fascia

T3a: Tumor extends into the renal vein or its segmental branches, or invades the pelvicalyceal system, or invades perirenal and/or renal sinus fat but not beyond Gerota’s fascia

T3b: Tumor extends into the vena cava below the diaphragm

T3c: Tumor extends into the vena cava above the diaphragm or invades the wall of the vena cava

T4

Tumor invades beyond Gerota’s fascia (including contiguous extension into the ipsilateral adrenal gland)

Regional lymph node (N)

NX

Regional lymph nodes cannot be assessed

N0

No regional lymph node metastasis

N1

Metastasis in regional lymph node(s)

Distant metastasis (M)

M0

No distant metastasis

M1

Distant metastasis

about.evidence_based_medicine_en:
The 2017 version of the TNM staging system is only slightly modified compared to the previous version published in 2009 (AJCC 2017 & Paner 2018). The modifications mainly relate to the specific language describing the T3a subgroup.

The 2009 staging system had been previously validated by two large studies. The first study was a multi-center study of 16 centers from Italy including 5,339 patients treated with radical or partial nephrectomy (Novara 2010). The second study was a single institution study of 3996 patients treated with radical or partial nephrectomy (Kim 2011). Both studies validated the 2009 TNM staging system while still showing some overlap in prognoses among patients classified into different categories. Moreover, the second study showed that the 2009 TNM staging system had only a modestly improved c-index compared to the 2002 version (0.850 vs 0.848).

Original/Primary Reference.text: American Joint Committee on Cancer (AJCC). AJCC Cancer Staging Manual. 8th ed. New York: Springer; 2017.

Other References.text: Choyke PL, Amis ES Jr, Bigongiari LR, Bluth EI, Bush WH Jr, Fritzsche P, Holder L, Newhouse JH, Sandler CM, Segal AJ, Resnick MI, Rutsky EA. Renal cell carcinoma staging. American College of Radiology. ACR Appropriateness Criteria. Radiology. 2000 Jun;215 Suppl:721-5.
Ng CS, Wood CG, Silverman PM, Tannir NM, Tamboli P, Sandler CM. Renal cell carcinoma: diagnosis, staging, and surveillance. AJR Am J Roentgenol. 2008;191(4):1220-32.
NCCN Clinical Practice Guidelines in Oncology: Kidney Cancer. V 2.2014.
Weill Cornell Medical College James Buchanan Brady Foundation Department of Urology. Renal Cell Carcinoma.
Paner GP, Stadler WM, Hansel DE, Montironi R, Lin DW, Amin MB. Updates in the Eighth Edition of the Tumor-Node-Metastasis Staging Classification for Urologic Cancers. Eur Urol. 2018;73(4):560-569.

Validation.text: Novara G, et. al. Validation of the 2009 TNM version in a large multi-institutional cohort of patients treated for renal cell carcinoma: are further improvements needed? Eur Urol. 2010 Oct;58(4):588-95.

Kim SP, Alt AL, Weight CJ, et al. Independent validation of the 2010 American Joint Committee on Cancer TNM classification for renal cell carcinoma: results from a large, single institution cohort. J Urol. 2011;185(6):2035-9.
Escudier B, et al. Renal cell carcinoma: ESMO Clinical Practice Guidelines for diagnosis, treatment and follow-up. Ann Oncol (2014) 25 (suppl 3): iii49-iii56.

expert_name.description: Ziad Bakouny, MD, MSc, is a postdoctoral genitourinary oncology research fellow at the Dana-Farber Cancer Institute/Harvard Cancer Center. Dr. Bakouny received his medical degree from the University of Saint Joseph in Beirut, Lebanon, during which time he concurrently obtained a master’s in biomechanics and medical imaging. He has published more than 30 peer-reviewed papers, presented 70 abstracts at international scientific conferences, and received various awards for his research, including a Conquer Cancer Foundation merit award at the American Society of Clinical Oncology and Society for Immunotherapy of Cancer’s clinical immuno-oncology symposium. His areas of interest include genitourinary oncology, biomarker research, and bioinformatics.
expert_name.name: Ziad Bakouny, MD, MSc

creator_info.about_en: Brian I. Rini, MD, is a professor of medicine at the Cleveland Clinic Lerner College of Medicine at Case Western Reserve University. He is also a physician in the medical oncology department at Cleveland Clinic. Dr. Rini’s primary research is focused on renal cell carcinoma and prostate cancer.
